displaytitle: Thenot Remonstrates with Colinet; Lightfoot in the Distance
dimensions: sheet trimmed to block: 3.5 x 7.5 cm. (1 3/8 x 2 15/16 in.)
creditline: Gift of Frank Jewett Mather Jr.

titles.title: Thenot Remonstrates with Colinet; Lightfoot in the Distance

makers.displaymaker: William Blake, 1757–1827; born and died London, England

texts.textentryhtml: In 1819, William Blake was commissioned to provide a series of illustrations for The Pastorals of Virgil, with a Course of English Reading for Schools, edited by Robert John Thornton. This grade-school primer included “Thenot and Colinet,” a poem written in 1748 by the British writer Ambrose Philips as an imitation of Virgil’s first Eclogue, composed by the Roman poet between 44 and 38 B.C. in praise of the moral and spiritual virtues of pastoral life. Although Blake’s illustrations to Philips’s stanzas are miniscule in scale and childlike in their simplicity, these wood engravings had a profound influence on subsequent British artists, who admired their medieval appearance.
texts.remarks: K2 Corridor: “A Single Drop of Ink for a Mirror”: Nineteenth-Century British Literature and the Visual Arts (group chat for x1938-58 a through x1938-58 e)

texts.textentryhtml: John Linnell (1792-1882); with Frank Jewett Mather, Jr. (1868-1953) by 1938
